**Why It Matters**

Brown dwarfs are cosmic "failed stars"—objects too small to sustain nuclear fusion like our Sun, but too massive to be planets. Think of them as the missing link between stars and giant planets like Jupiter. Understanding these mysterious objects helps us piece together how stellar systems form and evolve. More importantly, brown dwarfs serve as stand-ins for studying giant exoplanets, since they have similar temperatures and atmospheric compositions but are much easier to observe directly. By mapping their precise locations and movements through space, astronomers can uncover clues about planetary formation and identify the best candidates for future atmospheric studies that might reveal signs of habitability.

**What They Did**

Using a specialized telescope in Arizona, researchers spent over five years tracking 173 brown dwarfs with extraordinary precision. They measured two crucial things: parallax (how much an object appears to shift position as Earth orbits the Sun, revealing its distance) and proper motion (how fast it moves across the sky). Think of parallax like closing one eye, then the other, and watching how a nearby object seems to jump against the background—the bigger the jump, the closer the object. The team took an average of 62 separate observations of each brown dwarf over more than five years, allowing them to track movements as small as a few milliarcseconds—equivalent to measuring the width of a quarter from 100 miles away.

**Key Findings**

The study created the most precise distance and motion measurements ever obtained for 116 brown dwarfs, with first-time measurements for 16 others. Their typical distance uncertainty was just 1.51 milliarcseconds, translating to remarkably accurate distance measurements. The team also discovered and characterized multiple binary brown dwarf systems—pairs of these objects orbiting each other. They identified several categories of special objects, including unusually young brown dwarfs, metal-poor "subdwarfs," and wide companions to other stars.

**Looking Forward**

This treasure trove of precise measurements creates a foundation for future brown dwarf and exoplanet research. Knowing exact distances allows astronomers to determine these objects' true brightness and size, crucial for understanding their atmospheres. As next-generation telescopes come online, this catalog will help identify the best targets for detailed atmospheric analysis—studies that will refine our techniques for eventually analyzing the atmospheres of potentially habitable exoplanets around other stars.

papers.title: Constraining the size, shape, and albedo of the large Trans-Neptunian Object (28978) Ixion with multi-chord stellar occultations
papers.abstract: Trans-Neptunian objects (TNOs) are among the most primitive remnants of the early Solar System, and constraining their sizes, shapes, albedos, and surface properties is essential for understanding their origin and evolution. Stellar occultations provide highly accurate size and shape measurements for TNOs, while photometry constrains their albedo and surface colours. (28978) Ixion is one of the largest TNOs and a prominent Plutino, making it a key target for comparative studies. We aim to constrain Ixion's projected size, shape, absolute magnitude, geometric albedo, and surface colours, and to search for evidence of an atmosphere or circum-object material. We analysed stellar occultation campaigns by Ixion conducted between 2020 and 2023 within the Lucky Star collaboration, comprising 51 observations from eight events, including 30 positive detections. Five multi-chord events enabled a global limb fit and an accurate reconstruction of Ixion's projected shape. The occultations reveal a slightly elongated limb well represented by a single projected ellipse, yielding an area-equivalent diameter of $D_{\mathrm{equiv}} = 696.78^{+10.75}_{-8.87}$ km and an apparent oblateness $ε' = 0.081^{+0.004}_{-0.010}$. Typical radial residuals of order $\sim$10 km indicate a largely stable shape across epochs, with modest epoch-dependent variations. Calibrated photometric data yield an absolute magnitude of $H_V = 3.845 \pm 0.006$, a phase-curve slope of $β= 0.1301 \pm 0.0078$ mag deg$^{-1}$, and a visible geometric albedo of $p_V = 0.106^{+0.003}_{-0.003}$, with colours consistent with moderately red TNO surfaces. No atmosphere or circum-object material is detected down to our sensitivity limits. The best-sampled event also allows a precise measurement of the angular diameter of the occulted star Gaia DR3 4056440205544338944, $θ_\star = 0.670 \pm 0.010$ mas.

**Why It Matters**

Deep in the outer reaches of our solar system, beyond Neptune's orbit, lies a treasure trove of ancient objects that hold secrets about how our cosmic neighborhood formed 4.6 billion years ago. These "Trans-Neptunian Objects" are like cosmic time capsules—frozen remnants from the dawn of our solar system that have remained largely unchanged since the planets first took shape. By studying these distant worlds, we can piece together the story of how Earth and the other planets came to be, and better understand the violent, chaotic early days when our solar system was still under construction.

**What They Did**

Scientists used a clever technique called stellar occultation to measure one of these distant objects, named Ixion after a figure from Greek mythology. Think of it like watching a solar eclipse, but in reverse—instead of the moon blocking the sun, researchers watched as Ixion passed in front of distant stars, creating tiny shadows on Earth. By timing exactly when the starlight disappeared and reappeared from multiple locations around the globe, they could trace Ixion's outline with incredible precision. Between 2020 and 2023, teams coordinated 51 observations across eight separate events, capturing 30 successful measurements as Ixion's shadow swept across Earth.

**Key Findings**

Ixion turned out to be quite large—about 697 kilometers across, making it roughly the size of Texas or slightly smaller than Pluto's moon Charon. It's not perfectly round but rather slightly oval-shaped, like a cosmic football that's been gently squeezed. The object reflects only about 11% of the sunlight that hits it, making it darker than our moon but typical for these ancient, carbon-rich worlds. Surprisingly, Ixion appears to be quite stable, maintaining the same basic shape across different observations.

**Looking Forward**

These precise measurements help scientists understand how the largest building blocks of planets formed and evolved. As we discover more exoplanets around other stars, knowing how objects like Ixion behave gives us crucial context for understanding planetary systems beyond our own—bringing us closer to answering fundamental questions about how common Earth-like worlds might be in the universe.

papers.title: True Masses using RV data with Hipparcos and Gaia Astrometry
papers.abstract: Long-period companions are detected and characterized thanks to long-baseline radial velocity surveys. Combining Doppler time-series with astrometry, and in particular with proper motion anomalies technique, it is possible to put strong constraints on their orbital inclination and true mass. This work aims to present a model that combines Hipparcos and Gaia astrometric data with radial velocity measurements to constrain the orbital inclinations and true masses of long-period companions. Additionally, we re-analyse a small sample of targets that have not yet been studied using this combined approach. This research leverages the simultaneous modelling of proper motion anomalies and radial velocities, in conjunction with an analysis of the sensitivity curve. This approach serves not only as a verification of the parameters but also as a means to acquire valuable insights into planetary systems. The new analyses reveal that some of the targets classified as brown dwarfs or small-mass stars have a planetary nature. HD 5388 b and HD 6718 b are likely planets. HD 141937 b is likely a planet, but the current dataset does not allow us to firmly constrain its true mass. HD 16760 b belongs to the brown dwarf regime and it has a probable second companion. 30 Ari B b falls within the stellar regime, but the presence of an additional stellar companion could compromise the reliability of the final results. For HD 148427 b, HD 96127 b and HIP 65891 b we determined a range for the orbital inclinations.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to weigh an invisible bowling ball by watching how it makes a visible basketball wobble. That's essentially the challenge astronomers face when studying distant planets orbiting other stars. For decades, scientists have been detecting these "exoplanets" by observing how they make their host stars wobble, but determining whether these unseen companions are actually planets, failed stars called brown dwarfs, or small regular stars has been incredibly difficult. This distinction matters enormously—planets might harbor life, while brown dwarfs and stars cannot support the conditions we associate with habitability. Getting accurate measurements helps us understand how planetary systems form and whether Earth-like worlds are common in our galaxy.

**What They Did**

The research team combined two different techniques to get a clearer picture of these mysterious companions. First, they used the traditional method of measuring how fast stars move toward and away from us—like listening to how an ambulance siren changes pitch as it approaches and recedes. Second, they added precise measurements of how stars move across the sky over many years, using data from two space telescopes, Hipparcos and Gaia. Think of it like tracking a person walking while carrying a heavy, shifting backpack—the extra weight affects both their forward progress and their side-to-side movement. By combining both types of measurements, the scientists could determine not just that these companions exist, but also their true masses and the angles of their orbits.

**Key Findings**

The team made some exciting reclassifications. Two objects previously thought to be brown dwarfs—HD 5388 b and HD 6718 b—are likely actual planets. Another object, HD 141937 b, also appears planetary, though more data is needed for confirmation. However, HD 16760 b confirmed its status as a brown dwarf, and the researchers discovered it probably has a second companion. They also found that 30 Ari B b is actually a small star, not a planet, though additional stellar companions in that system complicate the analysis.

**Looking Forward**

This research demonstrates how combining different observational techniques can revolutionize our understanding of distant worlds. As more precise astrometric data becomes available, astronomers will be able to create a more accurate census of planets versus other objects in our cosmic neighborhood. This could help answer fundamental questions about how common planetary systems like ours really are and guide future searches for potentially habitable worlds.

papers.title: Circumplanetary Disk Candidate in the Disk of HD 163296 Traced by Localized Emission from Simple Organics
papers.abstract: Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array observations suggest that the disc of HD 163296 is being actively shaped by embedded, yet unseen protoplanets, as indicated by numerous gas and dust substructures consistent with planet-disc interaction models. We report the first detection of simple organic molecules, HCN and C2H, tracing a candidate circumplanetary disc (CPD) in the HD 163296 system, located at an orbital radius of $R=88\pm7$ au and azimuth $φ=46\pm3^\circ$ (or $R=0.75''$, $\rm{PA}=350^\circ$ in projected sky coordinates), and originating near the midplane of the circumstellar disc. The signature is localised but spectrally resolved, and it overlaps with a previously reported planet candidate, P94, identified through kinematic perturbations traced by CO lines. We propose a scenario in which the observed chemical anomalies arise from increased heating driven by the forming planet and ongoing accretion through its CPD, facilitating the thermal desorption of species that would otherwise remain frozen out in the disc midplane, and potentially triggering the activation barriers of chemical reactions that lead to enhanced molecular production. Based on a first-order dynamical analysis of the HCN spectrum from the CPD--isolated with a 7$σ$ significance--we infer an upper limit on the planet mass of 1.8 $M_{\rm Jup}$, consistent with predictions from CO kinematics and constraints from direct imaging studies. By comparing the CPD sizes derived from our models with theoretical expectations where the CPD radius corresponds to roughly one-third of the planet's Hill radius, we favor CPD gas temperatures $T > 150$ K, planet masses $M_{\rm p} < 1.0$ $M_{\rm Jup}$, and CPD radii $R_{\rm CPD} < 2$ au.

# Scientists Spot a Baby Planet's Mini Solar System in the Making

**Why It Matters**

For the first time, astronomers have detected chemical fingerprints of what appears to be a mini solar system forming around a baby planet 330 light-years away. This discovery gives us an unprecedented glimpse into how planets grow and develop their own satellite systems—much like how Jupiter has its family of moons orbiting around it. Understanding this process helps us piece together how our own solar system formed billions of years ago, and reveals the incredible diversity of planetary systems throughout the galaxy. It's like watching a cosmic nursery in action, showing us that planet formation is far more complex and fascinating than we ever imagined.

**What They Did**

The research team used the powerful Atacama Large Millimeter Array—a collection of 66 radio dishes in Chile that work together like a giant telescope—to study a young star called HD 163296. This star is surrounded by a massive disk of gas and dust, the raw material from which planets form. The scientists weren't looking for the planet directly (it's too small and dim to see), but instead hunted for chemical clues. They detected two simple carbon-based molecules, HCN and C2H, concentrated in one specific spot within the disk. Think of it like finding a warm patch in a cold room—the heat signature tells you something interesting is happening there, even if you can't see the heat source itself.

**Key Findings**

The team found these molecules clustered around what appears to be a forming planet roughly the mass of Jupiter, orbiting about 88 times farther from its star than Earth orbits the Sun. The planet seems to have its own mini-disk of material swirling around it—a "circumplanetary disk" that could eventually form moons. The detection was remarkably precise, pinpointed to a specific location that matches predictions from previous studies. The planet's gravitational pull and heat are apparently warming up the surrounding material, causing frozen molecules to vaporize and become detectable.

**Looking Forward**

This breakthrough opens an entirely new way to hunt for forming planets by tracking their chemical signatures rather than trying to see them directly. It suggests that baby planets actively reshape their birth environments in ways we're only beginning to understand. Future observations could reveal how common these circumplanetary disks are and help us understand how moon systems develop—potentially identifying where future habitable worlds might emerge around distant stars.
